model_output:
Knowledge Inference within Expert Systems:

Definition and Theoretical Foundations:
(1970s; described in 2016 PDF [1]) An expert system is a knowledge-intensive software that can perform tasks requiring human expertise [1]. These systems are built upon two main components - a knowledge base and an inference engine. The inference engine makes inferences by determining how the system reasons using IF–THEN rules in the knowledge base [1]. The process of moving forward from known facts to conclusions that follow them is called forward chaining, while backward chaining refers to inferring the premises needed to deduce a given conclusion [1]. Evolution Across Publications:
(event year not stated; described in 2016 PDF [1]) The concept of expert systems emerged under the umbrella of Artificial Intelligence (AI) around mid-1970s and was transformed into an established branch of computer science as soon as convincing successes were attained [1]. As a result, various expert system building tools or shells have been developed to facilitate their construction process, known as knowledge engineering [1]. References:
[1] Expert_Systems.pdf (2016)
